definition[0]: to make someone feel very unhappy
example[0]: The thought of taking the exam again depressed him.
example[1]: It depresses me that nobody seems to care.
definition[1]: to prevent an economy from being as active and successful as it usually is
example[2]: Several factors combined to depress the American economy.
definition[2]: to press something down, especially a part of a machine
explanation[0]: In everyday English, people usually say they push (down) or press (down) a button rather than depress it:
example[4]: Push this button for cold water.
definition[3]: to reduce the value of prices or wages
example[6]: High interest rates may depress share prices.
definition[4]: to prevent an economy, industry, market etc from working properly or being as active as it usually is
example[7]: Overproduction was blamed for depressing oil markets.
definition[5]: to reduce the value of something such as prices or wages
example[8]: Competition between workers will depress wage levels.
example[9]: Profits have already been depressed by the recession.
